question: Should we support the New START Treaty?

content.source_1: U.S. Department of State, Fact Sheet (February 3, 2021) — Explains why the United States extended New START for five years, highlighting its verifiable limits (1,550 deployed strategic warheads; 700 deployed delivery systems; 800 launchers) and robust transparency measures (on‑site inspections, data exchanges, notifications) that enhance predictability and U.S. national security. https://www.state.gov/new-start-treaty-extension-and-its-benefits/
content.source_2: Hudson Institute analysis (Rebeccah L. Heinrichs et al., 2020–2021) — Argues against extending New START without major changes, contending the treaty ignores Russia’s large stockpile of nonstrategic nuclear weapons, doesn’t constrain Russia’s novel systems, and leaves China’s growing arsenal outside any limits, thereby disadvantaging the United States. https://www.hudson.org/foreign-policy-defense
content.source_3: Arms Control Association, “The New START Treaty at a Glance” (regularly updated) — Documents that both countries met the treaty’s central limits by February 5, 2018 and that, prior to Russia’s 2023 suspension, the regime had provided years of mutual inspections and thousands of notifications, strengthening strategic stability and reducing arms race pressures. https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/newstart
content.source_4: Congressional Research Service, IF11005 “The New START Treaty” (updated) — Neutral assessment noting key limitations: the treaty does not cover nonstrategic (tactical) nuclear weapons or third-country forces and has gaps regarding some emerging Russian systems; it outlines verification tools but underscores scope constraints that fuel ongoing policy debate. https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/details?prodcode=IF11005
content.source_5: Brookings Institution (Steven Pifer), “Five reasons to extend New START now” (October 29, 2020) — Makes the case that extension preserves transparency and predictability during U.S.–Russian nuclear modernization, supports deterrence at lower, verifiable levels, and buys time to pursue broader negotiations that could address China and new technologies. https://www.brookings.edu/articles/five-reasons-to-extend-new-start-now/
content.source_6: President of Russia, Address to the Federal Assembly (February 21, 2023) — Announces Russia’s suspension of participation in New START, halting inspections and data exchanges and casting doubt on the treaty’s functioning; framed as a response to U.S./NATO policies, this stance is cited by critics as evidence of arms control’s fragility with Moscow. http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/70565
